author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Death Changed My Life
description: I see now that life is a series of peaks and valleys, and it is a fool’s errand to try to flatten them out.
content: My oldest brother died more than a year ago, and that unspeakable loss changed me. I would say that it was the last straw, but there were so many last straws. I will simply say that it was in the final bale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Wildman
title: The Bat Mitzvah Question I Wasn’t Expecting: ‘Are We Safe at Synagogue?’
description: Finding hope in the darkness of cancer, Covid and Colleyville.
content: In many synagogues in America, especially large congregations like the one my family and I attend, children receive a date for their bar or bat mitzvah years in advance. This is the day that a child stands in front of the congregation and assumes the responsibilities of an adult, reading from the Torah and offering a commentary on the week’s teaching. It is a time of enormous celebration; it requires months of preparation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Sarah Palin v. New York Times Spotlights Push to Loosen Libel Law
description: The trial comes at a time when those who argue that news outlets should pay a steeper price for getting something wrong are more emboldened than they’ve been in decades.
content: When Donald J. Trump called for scrapping laws that offer the news media broad protection from libel suits — “We’re going to have people sue you like you’ve never got sued before,” he said in 2016 as he was running for president — many journalists and the lawyers who defend them brushed it off as an empty threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Jack Healy
title: For Many Who Marched, Jan. 6 Was Only the Beginning
description: To many of those who attended the Trump rally but who never breached the Capitol, that date wasn’t a dark day for the nation. It was a new start.
content: PHOENIX — There were moments when Paul Davis questioned his decision to join the crowd that marched on the United States Capitol last January. When he was publicly identified and fired from his job as a lawyer. When his fiancée walked out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Beholder of Beauty
description: André Leon Talley was the last great editor of a lost era.
content: There is a scene early in “The September Issue,” the 2009 documentary about the making of the year’s door-stopper Vogue magazine, that features a meeting between the designer Vera Wang, dressed down in a striped shirt and no makeup, and, like a character from an entirely different movie set, the editor André Leon Talley: very tall, very imposing, in dark glasses, silk tie and bespoke suit, swathed in a mink shawl. They are discussing the state of New York fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Russia-Ukraine, Omicron, N.F.L.: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Litter Boxes for Students Who Identify as Furries? Not So, Says School Official
description: A Michigan school superintendent debunked the rumor after a video from a December school board meeting resurfaced in which a speaker airs concerns about students who “identify as cats.”
content: It started with a comment at a school board meeting, which was later amplified by a Michigan state Republican leader, and culminated with a school superintendent explaining that, no, there were no litter boxes on school grounds for students to use if they identified as furries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson, Chelsia Rose Marcius and Nate Schweber
title: A Grim January Leaves Some New Yorkers Fearful for the City’s Future
description: New York is far safer and stronger than in the ’70s. But after a flood of sad news, many people are struggling to find grounds for optimism.
content: A fire in the Bronx choked an apartment building with thick black smoke, killing 17 people, many of them children. That was on the ninth day of January, a Sunday — the same day a teenage cashier at a Burger King in Manhattan was shot and killed during a robbery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Gonzaga revokes John Stockton’s season tickets over his refusal to wear masks.
description: Stockton has been a vocal opponent of Covid-19 vaccines and government measures to mitigate the virus.
content: John Stockton, one of the most celebrated basketball players in history, is barred from attending games at his alma mater, Gonzaga University, because of an unwillingness to comply with the school’s mask mandate. Stockton revealed that his season tickets were revoked in an interview with The Spokesman Review published on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: André Leon Talley in His Own Words
description: “We’re living in such a vulgar age!,” the unfiltered fashion editor once said.
content: André Leon Talley was the last of his kind: a fashion editor who operated without the filter of a corporate public relations apparatus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Asked a Woman on the Platform if She Had Any Tissues’
description: Helping hands in the subway, a tug of war on the Upper East Side and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.4 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: In Wuhan, China, the anniversary of the world’s first lockdown passes quietly.
description: As China battles the highly contagious Omicron variant shortly before the Winter Olympics are set to begin in Beijing, Wuhan has so far been spared.
content: Wuhan, the Chinese city where Covid-19 first emerged in late 2019, began the world’s first coronavirus lockdown two years ago Sunday, shutting down public transportation and restricting departures for what proved to be 76 days. Since that move — stunning at the time — lockdowns of varying sizes and strictness have been carried out around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Nino Cerruti, Designer Who Revolutionized Men's Wear, Dies at 91
description: He loosened up men’s suits with unstructured tailoring and supple fabrics. He also dressed generations of movie stars, onscreen and off.
content: Nino Cerruti, the dashing Italian fashion designer and textile scion who modernized men’s wear with his soft, unstructured tailoring and dressed generations of movie and television stars onscreen and off, died on Jan. 15 in Vercelli, Italy. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below, along with some solving tips and tricks by Wordplay’s own Deb Amlen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Clark Gillies, Rugged Star on Islanders’ Championship Teams, Dies at 67
description: He was part of the Trio Grande, along with Bryan Trottier and Mike Bossy, on teams that won the Stanley Cup four years in a row.
content: Clark Gillies, the rugged Hall of Fame left wing who helped take the Islanders to four consecutive Stanley Cup championships in the early 1980s, died on Friday at his home in Greenlawn on Long Island. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Documentary Critical of Disney, From the Disney Family
description: A harsh portrait of pay inequality at the company, premiering at Sundance on Monday, was directed by the granddaughter of one of the founders.
content: Three years ago, Abigail E. Disney began to publicly excoriate the Walt Disney Company for its “obscene” pay inequality, with Robert A. Iger, who was then chief executive, at one end of the scale and hourly theme park workers at the other. The company founded by her grandfather and great-uncle repeatedly returned fire, at one point calling her assertions a “gross and unfair exaggeration of the facts.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: A Grand Slam Streak Without (Yet) a Quarterfinal
description: Since 2007, Alizé Cornet of France hasn’t missed a single Grand Slam main draw.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — In an era of women’s tennis defined by volatility at the top, Alizé Cornet has been a constant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Dennis Smith, Firefighter Who Wrote Best Sellers, Dies at 81
description: “Report From Engine Co. 82” was the first of his 16 books. He also started Firehouse magazine and was the founding chairman of the New York City Fire Museum.
content: Dennis Smith, a teenage hellion and high school dropout who transformed himself into a famed New York City firefighter, a gritty best-selling author and a leading guardian for the safety of his colleagues and the public, died on Friday in Venice, Fla. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Ann Coulter Is Rooting for a Trump-DeSantis Throw-Down. She’s Not Alone.
description: The former president and the governor of Florida are on a collision course for the future of the G.OP.
content: Ann Coulter has a gift for pushing just the right buttons to inflict maximum irritation. She has been a top-tier troll since Donald Trump was little more than a failed casino magnate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Olympians Face a Daunting Final Qualifying Event: Staying Healthy
description: For athletes going to Beijing, years of sacrifice could go to waste if they get the coronavirus now. To avoid it, they’re hunkering down, shunning friends and skipping competitions.
content: They’ve come too far, for far too long, to mess it all up now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: In Greece, a String of Killings Pushes Domestic Abuse Into the Spotlight
description: Several deadly assaults on women by their partners appear to have encouraged more victims to speak up in a country where such attacks have rarely been publicly discussed.
content: ATHENS — One woman was suffocated, her body found next to her baby. Another was pushed off a cliff. Yet another was stabbed 23 times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: French Adventurer Attempting to Row Solo Across the Atlantic Is Missing
description: Jean-Jacques Savin, 75, activated distress beacons on Thursday and Friday, his team said. On Saturday, the Portuguese Navy found his boat, but not his body, near the Azores.
content: The French adventurer Jean-Jacques Savin has disappeared while attempting to row solo across the Atlantic, according to a statement on Sunday from the Portuguese Navy, which said his boat was found overturned on Saturday near the Azores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arif Rafiq
title: Why Pakistan’s Army Wants the U.S. Back in the Region
description: As U.S.-China competition intensifies, Pakistan’s army fears getting trapped in a cul-de-sac with Beijing.
content: For years, Chinese and Pakistani leaders have described their relationship, forged by a common rivalry with their neighbor India, as “sweeter than honey.” But the Pakistani Army’s view of the relationship with China appears to be souring — and diverging from the political leadership’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘The Gilded Age’ Review: Dime-Store ‘Downton’
description: Ten years in the making, this Julian Fellowes period drama set in New York is a pale echo of the original that inspired it.
content: Julian Fellowes chased his new series, “The Gilded Age,” for a decade. Call it his white whale. Beginning Monday on HBO, you can watch it drag him and a large, talented cast beneath the waves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: A Legacy Lives On in Brooklyn
description: 90 years after its closure, a former New York Times printing plant now provides space for a new generation of journalists.
content: From the sidewalk, it’s easy to miss. On the corner of Third Avenue and Pacific Street in Brooklyn, N.Y., etched on a bronze plaque above a blue door leading to the theater of Brooklyn High School of the Arts, is a historical clue: An ornate inscription reads, “The New York Times.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: For small U.S. towns, just one coronavirus infection can put governance at risk.
description: In Marvell, Ark., a tiny Mississippi Delta town of 855 residents tucked into a sea of cotton, soy bean and corn fields, Lee Guest is a particularly essential essential worker.
content: In Marvell, Ark., a tiny Mississippi Delta town of 855 residents tucked into a sea of cotton, soy bean and corn fields, Lee Guest is a particularly essential essential worker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: A YouTuber’s Plane Crash Draws Doubts From Aviation Experts
description: The video from December shows Trevor Jacob cursing in panic before leaping with a parachute out of a small plane. Some experts wonder if the crash was a publicity stunt.
content: The YouTube video with the attention-grabbing title “I Crashed My Plane” begins with Trevor Jacob piloting a small aircraft with several cameras attached, showing off sweeping views of sepia and green above the Los Padres National Forest in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman
title: Pakistan says only fully vaccinated people will be allowed in mosques.
description: Pakistani officials have introduced a series of tough new coronavirus restrictions — including barring anyone not fully vaccinated from entering mosques for prayer — after recording the country’s highest known daily number of new cases since the pandemic began.
content: Pakistani officials have introduced a series of tough new coronavirus restrictions — including barring anyone not fully vaccinated from entering mosques for prayer — after recording the country’s highest known daily number of new cases since the pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs and Rory Doyle
title: A Shrinking Band of Southern Nurses, Neck-Deep in Another Covid Wave
description: The exodus of medical workers during the pandemic has been especially brutal for the small, nonprofit safety-net hospitals where millions of Americans seek care.
content: PASCAGOULA, Miss. — Bobbie Anne Sison was heading to the hospital just before dawn when she got a panicked call from one of her best nurses saying she couldn’t come to work because her car had overheated on Route 63. Ms. Sison, a nurse manager at Pascagoula Hospital, slammed on the brakes, made a U-turn and raced to fetch her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Gunfire Rattles Burkina Faso’s Capital as Soldiers Revolt
description: The government denied rumors of a coup, but soldiers who want changes to the fight against Islamists appear to have taken control of several military bases.
content: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Gunfire erupted at military bases across this conflict-hit West African country early on Sunday as part of an attempted mutiny by soldiers angered by their government’s failure to halt a wave of Islamist militant attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Ngannou Keeps U.F.C. Heavyweight Crown Amid Contract Dispute
description: After beating Ciryl Gane, Francis Ngannou did not get the usual postmatch treatment from the U.F.C.’s president, Dana White, who faces renewing the champion’s contract.
content: To find clues about the soured relationship between Francis Ngannou, the heavyweight champion in the Ultimate Fighting Championship, and Dana White, the organization’s president, note White’s hard-to-ignore absences on Saturday night in Anaheim, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: A U.K. Accusation
description: British officials say Russia is trying to establish a pro-Kremlin government in Ukraine.
content: The British government said that the Kremlin appeared to be developing plans to install a pro-Moscow leader in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hwaida Saad, Asmaa al-Omar and Ben Hubbard
title: ‘Now There Is No One’: The Lament of One of the Last Christians in a Syrian City
description: Michel Butros al-Jisri is among the few Christians left from a once-vibrant community in Idlib on the brink of disappearing. The city, in the only territory in Syria still controlled by rebels, is ruled by Islamists.
content: On Christmas Day, Michel Butros al-Jisri, one of the last Christians in the Syrian city of Idlib, didn’t attend services, because the Islamist rebels who control the area had long since locked up the church. Nor did he gather with friends and relatives to celebrate around a tree because nearly all of his fellow Christians have either died or fled during Syria’s 10-year civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Can Works Like ‘Don’t Look Up’ Get Us Out of Our Heads?
description: In the doomsday smash and Bo Burnham’s pandemic musical “Inside,” themes of climate change, digital distraction and inequality merge and hit home.
content: An Everest-size comet is hurtling toward Earth, and in exactly six months and 14 days, the planet will be shattered to pieces, leaving every living creature to perish in a cataclysm of fire and flood. In “Don’t Look Up,” Netflix’s hit climate-apocalypse film, this news largely bounces off the American public like a rubber ball. And they return to their phones with a collective “meh” — opting to doomscroll instead of acknowledging certain doom IRL.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: Biden Weighs Deploying Thousands of Troops to Eastern Europe and Baltics
description: The president is also considering deploying warships and aircraft to NATO allies, in what would be a major shift from its restrained stance on Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden is considering deploying several thousand U.S. troops, as well as warships and aircraft, to NATO allies in the Baltics and Eastern Europe, an expansion of American military involvement amid mounting fears of a Russian incursion into Ukraine, according to administration officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: A Tricky First Case for the Man Who Wrote the Rules on Nazi Looted Art
description: The diplomat and lawyer who helped write the treaty used around the world to guide restitution claims is representing the family of a childhood friend, which has been sued to surrender a painting.
content: Few people have done more to advance the cause of people seeking to recover property lost to the Nazis in World War II than Stuart E. Eizenstat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: Biden’s Pandemic Fight: Inside the Setbacks of the First Year
description: The administration has gotten much right, but its response has been hampered by confusing messaging, a lack of focus on testing, fear of political blowback and the coronavirus’s unpredictability.
content: WASHINGTON — Dr. Rochelle Walensky was stunned. Working from her home outside Boston on a Friday night in late July, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention had just learned from members of her staff that vaccinated Americans were spreading the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: ‘Miserable and Dangerous’: A Failed Chinese Promise in Serbia
description: Poor conditions for Vietnamese workers building a $900 million tire factory underscore a chasm between the promise of investment from China and grim realities on the ground.
content: ZRENJANIN, Serbia — Seeking escape from grinding poverty in northern Vietnam, the 43-year-old farmer labored for years on construction sites in Kuwait and Uzbekistan before being offered a ticket to what he was told would be “the promised land” — Europe, and a job with a good salary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Virtual schooling hurt students. So why is the federal government paying for virtual tutoring?
description: When Education Secretary Miguel Cardona appeared before Congress in September to promote the Biden administration’s stimulus funding for schools, he promised tutoring to help students make up missed learning, as well as an end to instruction through screens.
content: When Education Secretary Miguel Cardona appeared before Congress in September to promote the Biden administration’s stimulus funding for schools, he promised tutoring to help students make up missed learning, as well as an end to instruction through screens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: An Abrupt Ending for Aaron Rodgers Brings a Rush of Uncertainty
description: Rodgers, though likely to win his second straight M.V.P. Award, now must contemplate his future with the Green Bay Packers much sooner than he had hoped.
content: GREEN BAY, Wis. — This is how it all ended for Aaron Rodgers on Saturday night: a football fluttering between the uprights, men in scarlet parkas scampering onto the field, snowflakes falling like so many opportunities lost and gone forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: André, by Bill
description: Two of fashion’s greats, André Leon Talley and Bill Cunningham, were wonderful foils for each other.
content: If the world of fabulous notables is divided between those who are famous mostly for what they do and those who are famous for who they are, André Leon Talley was difficult to define precisely because he was so much of both. He wrote well without fitting the conventional definition of a writer and styled great photo shoots without really being described as a stylist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Badal Roy, Who Fused Indian Rhythms With Jazz, Is Dead at 82
description: He collaborated across cultures, playing tabla with Miles Davis, Ornette Coleman, John McLaughlin and others in the jazz world and beyond, including Yoko Ono.
content: Badal Roy, an Indian tabla player whose drumming propelled East-West fusions for some of the most prominent musicians in and out of jazz, died on Tuesday in Wilmington, Del. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Matthew Stafford, in a reversal, seals a Rams win in the final minutes.
description: Stafford’s interceptions have dogged him this season, but his decisive heave to Cooper Kupp late in the game helped set up the Rams’ win over the Buccaneers on Sunday.
content: TAMPA, Fla. — Rams kicker Matt Gay’s kick sneaked inside the left upright as the game’s final four seconds ticked away, giving Los Angeles a 30-27 win over Tampa Bay on Sunday to reach the N.F.C. championship game, where they will host the San Francisco 49ers, who eliminated the Green Bay Packers on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: The 49ers complete their upset after the Packers’ special teams flubs.
description: San Francisco will move on to play either the Los Angeles Rams or the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in the N.F.C. championship game.
content: GREEN BAY, Wis. — Robbie Gould’s kick sailed through the uprights, and as his San Francisco teammates, bundled in red parkas, scampered onto the grass Saturday night, the Green Bay Packers just stood on their sideline. They had not lost all season at Lambeau Field, not in warm weather or temperate conditions or the winter chill, but a certain finality had now descended amid the snowfall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Rises and Shines
description: John Guzzetta throws a touchdown with this puzzle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Rise and shine, solvers! Or, if you’re solving this puzzle at 6 p.m. on Sunday because your insatiable appetite for crosswords means you can’t possibly wait a minute longer to dig in, then stay awake and continue shining.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Bengals overcome sacks and seeding to shock No. 1 Titans on the final play.
description: The Bengals kicked a field goal on the last play to beat Tennessee, 19-16, in a game that was mostly dominated by each defense.
content: NASHVILLE — The Cincinnati Bengals last week broke their 31-year playoff drought, and with a young, explosive offense, seemed like this year’s dark horse contender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: A Big Bet on Gaming
description: Intel announces plans for a $20 billion chip manufacturing complex in Ohio. With Omicron beginning a retreat, is a “new normal” coming? And the Fed meets, with inflation high on the agenda.
content: Microsoft on Monday announced plans to buy the video game company Activision Blizzard for almost $70 billion, its biggest deal ever. The company said the acquisition would help it compete in the so-called Metaverse, the nascent virtual world where some technologists believe we’ll soon live second lives. But Microsoft’s more immediate objective is probably to strengthen its gaming platform. Just as Netflix acquires content to compete for streaming viewers’ attention and subscription fees, Microsoft’s purchase of Activision — the maker of popular games like Call of Duty and Candy Crush — may bolster the library of games for Xbox Game Pass, Microsoft’s $10-a-month Netflix-style video game subscription service. The size of the deal, and the possibility that Microsoft could make some popular Activision titles exclusive to its platform, could bring renewed antitrust scrutiny to the company from federal regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Social Security Opens to Survivors of Same-Sex Couples Who Could Not Marry
description: Challenging a policy that limited survivor’s benefits to married couples, even though some couples were legally barred from marriage, took years.
content: Helen Thornton and Margery Brown began dating in 1979. After just a few months, Ms. Thornton said, “I knew that I wanted to spend the rest of my life with this person, and Margie felt the same way.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 23, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 23, 2022.
content: An article on Thursday about Silvio Berlusconi’s presidential campaign misspelled the given name of a lawmaker formerly with the anti-establishment Five Star Movement. He is Cristian Romaniello, not Christian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward and Patricia Mazzei
title: Former President of Florida International University Explains Sudden Exit
description: On Sunday, Mark B. Rosenberg said he created “discomfort for a valued employee.”
content: The former president of Florida International University in Miami revealed the reasons for his sudden resignation last week: He said that he had “caused discomfort for a valued employee.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 23, 2022
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Cameroon Nightclub Fire Kills at Least 16
description: The blaze was caused by explosions from fireworks used in the venue, the government said in a statement reported by news agencies.
content: A fire at a nightclub in Cameroon’s capital, Yaoundé, in the early hours of Sunday left at least 16 people dead and eight others seriously injured, according to news agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘The Hang’ Review: Taylor Mac Enfolds Us When We Need It Most
description: This opera, by Mac and Matt Ray, is as much a celebration of theater itself as it is an example of the communion humans crave but have been deprived of.
content: In stiletto heels and cascading lilac gown, with flowers for hair and blossoms in his beard, Socrates is dying rather leisurely, surrounded by acolytes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Ashleigh Barty Mixes It Up and Heads to Australian Open Quarterfinals
description: Barty, the world No. 1, kept Amanda Anisimova, who upset Naomi Osaka in the previous round, moving and out of sync in the fourth round. Barbora Krejcikova also advanced.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — New day, very different opponent: That remains the cruel beauty of tennis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Fauci cautions against overconfidence but says the U.S. wave looks like it’s ‘going in the right direction.’
description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci did say that there “may be a bit more pain and suffering with hospitalizations in those areas of the country” with lower vaccination rates.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, sounded cautiously optimistic on Sunday that the Omicron wave was peaking nationally in the United States and that the coronavirus cases could fall to manageable levels in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Britain Pursues More Muscular Role in Standoff With Russia on Ukraine
description: With a late-night announcement about Russian meddling in Ukraine, the U.K. signaled its aim to be a player in Europe’s security crisis — even as scandals besiege Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
content: LONDON — Britain seized the world’s attention on Saturday by accusing President Vladimir V. Putin of plotting to install a pro-Russian leader in Ukraine, a dramatic late-night announcement that instantly thrust it on to the front lines of the most dangerous security crisis in Europe in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: At the Australian Open, Taylor Fritz Finally Breaks Through
description: The American has reached the fourth round of a Grand Slam tournament for the first time in his career, and he credits believing in himself through good times and bad.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Though he is only 24, Taylor Fritz had been waiting a long time for the breakthrough he finally reached at this Australian Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Donald Trump Tries His Hand at Wordle
description: Colin Jost and Pete Davidson provided an update on their purchase of a retired Staten Island Ferry boat, in this episode hosted by Will Forte.
content: It’s the viral phenomenon that gets picked apart on social media, where you throw out random words and see what gets a response — but first, the “Saturday Night Live” opening sketch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raul Roman, Lauren Kelly, Rafe H. Andrews and Nick Parisse
title: Can We Turn a Desert Into a Forest?
description: After years of planting trees, farmers in Niger have begun to see results.
content: In the last decade, millions of Africans in the Sahel, a region of semiarid land that stretches for thousands of miles below the Sahara, have been displaced by violence and food and economic insecurity. Climate change is partly to blame — droughts and floods are growing longer and more frequent. But surging population growth, deforestation and overgrazing have also contributed to denuding much of the land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Tom Brady’s frustrating first half ends with interception.
description: The Buccaneers quarterback has yet to throw a touchdown, and was called for the first unsportmanlike conduct penalty of his career.
content: Tom Brady was flagged for unsportsmanlike conduct during the second quarter after complaining to the officials about what looked to be a hit to his face by Rams linebacker Von Miller.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: For Winter Olympians, the last hurdle before the competition is staying healthy.
description: They’ve come too far, for far too long, to mess it all up now.
content: They’ve come too far, for far too long, to mess it all up now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: This Ancient Crab Had Unusually Huge Eyes
description: A study of fossils from Colombia suggests that a prehistoric shellfish hunted prey with remarkably sharp vision.
content: Modern, adult crabs are not renowned for their swimming ability or their vision. They scuttle across the floors of silent seas, hardly reliant on small eyes as they scavenge or graze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esha Ray
title: As New York reports glimmers of hope, states in the West are under pressure.
description: As New York and some of its neighbors in the Northeast continued to see signs of hope in declining case numbers and positivity rates this week, states on the West Coast were reporting some of their worst known caseloads since the pandemic began.
content: As New York and some of its neighbors in the Northeast continued to see signs of hope in declining case numbers and positivity rates this week, states on the West Coast were reporting some of their worst known caseloads since the pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Workers at REI Store in Manhattan Seek to Form Retailer’s Only Union
description: In filing for a union election, employees of the outdoor equipment retailer cited safety during the pandemic, among other concerns.
content: Employees at an REI store in Manhattan filed for a union election on Friday, making the outdoor equipment and apparel retailer the latest prominent service-industry employer whose workers have sought to unionize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: How a Nostalgic Novel About Spain’s Heartland Joined the Political Fray
description: Ana Iris Simón wrote “Feria” to depict a way of life she fears is vanishing. She didn’t expect its message to be embraced by conservatives in her country.
content: CAMPO DE CRIPTANA, Spain — In her debut novel, “Feria,” Ana Iris Simón begins with a poignant admission: “I’m jealous of the life that my parents had at my age.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Did the Stimulus Fuel Inflation Rates? A Policy Debate Heats Up.
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 23, 2022.
content: “To the extent that we got more heat, we got a lot more growth for it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: As U.S. Strikes Syria Prison Held by ISIS, Young Detainees Are Caught in Crossfire
description: Almost 700 child detainees are being held in the prison still under siege four days after ISIS launched an attack to free detainees
content: BAGHDAD — An American-backed militia that has waged four days of deadly battles to dislodge Islamic State fighters from a prison in northeast Syria warned on Sunday that the jihadists were using more than 600 boys detained in the complex as “human shields.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Dan Einstein, Champion of Singer-Songwriters, Is Dead at 61
description: He operated independent record labels for John Prine and Steve Goodman that took a critically praised (and award-winning) artist-driven approach.
content: NASHVILLE — Dan Einstein, a Grammy-winning independent record producer who championed the careers of John Prine and Steve Goodman, died here on Jan. 15. He was 61.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: For Small Towns With Small Work Forces, Omicron Means Small Margins for Error
description: In large cities and rural towns, the Omicron variant has workers calling in sick with Covid-19. But in the small towns, it is often hard to find a Plan B.
content: In Marvell, Ark., a tiny Mississippi Delta town of 855 residents tucked into a sea of cotton, soy bean and corn fields, Lee Guest is a particularly essential essential worker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deesha Philyaw
title: Weike Wang’s Antisocial Novel, ‘Joan Is Okay’
description: The author of “Chemistry” returns with a wry and awkward heroine who prefers the company of machines to her fellow humans.
content: JOAN IS OKAY By Weike Wang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Nelson Peltz Takes Aim at Unilever
description: An activist investor adds pressure as Unilever seeks a new strategic direction.
content: LONDON — Only days ago, Unilever suffered a big defeat when it was forced to drop its $68 billion bid for GlaxoSmithKline’s consumer health business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo and Dan Powell
title: The Sunday Read: ‘How Disgust Explains Everything’
description: Disgust is one of the primal emotions that define, and explain, humanity.
content: What is “disgust”? Molly Young, a journalist with The New York Times, considers the evolutionary and social uses of this “universal aspect of life” to identify the impact of disgust in its physical, psychological and linguistic manifestations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is the U.S. on the Verge of a Civil War?
description: Readers respond to columns by Ross Douthat and Michelle Goldberg. Also: Bosses who are jerks; voter suppression, then and now.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A (Very Late) Christmas Dinner
description: Let nothing stop you from making a festive dinner of ham and scalloped potatoes on any old Sunday.
content: Good morning. I finally had my Christmas dinner last week, deep in the Maine woods, together with family for the first time in months. It was a supermarket feast: Eric Kim’s recipe for root beer ham, alongside sautéed green beans and some scalloped potatoes made on the fly — thin-sliced baking potatoes layered with dots of butter and sprinkles of salt and black pepper, then topped with a mixture of Cheddar and Swiss, and a healthy cup of half-and-half, baked until bubbly and spotted with brown.
source.name: The New York Times
